13E4E1BF0D25494FB467D8E110A8ECD0.description: Reflect on recorded data to make conclusions.

E88F6B58B6684341906EDD02BE1C4B95.description: Demonstrate safety and respect during investigations.

10591B88B60C4E0DAE485B8DC31AAE95.description: Predict the answer to a question.

A53AE3484D574952AF31A519916F7043.description: Recording data helps ensure observations can be referenced in the future.

94EFB0B35EED47D08EE960CB8C12948A.description: Investigations are carried out to try to understand the world.

F4E8F9F508E548BD81C2202346965591.description: Scientists can keep records of data in record books or computers.

60E4FD51985C4903A873E0E0C6E20A55.description: Observations can be recorded as data in many ways, such as words, drawings, photographs, numbers and counts and sound and video recordings

E4608E201A8C4AC28E77D5854A7C85DD.description: Observations can be made by using the senses.

C1159202B22F4859977BF003CD8F4B2B.description: A conclusion is an answer to a question based on gathered data.

81151885A2654A36B38E59CB4B6DA91A.description: A prediction is a likely answer to a question based on current understanding.

70A0FFD4A60E477D8A73993AD135D8AE.description: Steps followed during an investigation include asking questions, making predictions, gathering data, forming conclusions

8D4ACE4EAB324EC298B590370221016D.description: Investigations are carried out by a variety of individuals or groups, such as teachers, students, scientists, police and doctors

F067F87BBD7343A79195D5E8A39D6D1B.description: Investigations can be sparked by curiosity.

6C3EAEF3566D4AA1B5D24F4A282233D5.description: The skills and knowledge required to carry out an investigation can be learned.

8735380630AE4963A47F5D92387FAC17.description: Students engage in and describe investigation.

1EF73527E8FF40DD9273AB1ED12B6272.description: Scientific Methods: Investigation of the physical world is enhanced through the use of scientific methods that attempt to remove human biases and increase objectivity.

1AFD26266D0F41FBAE1EB866B3C486AB.description: Exchange ideas for creating three-step instructions that achieve a desired outcome.

BA9E26D865864C4394AD5639945B854A.description: Sequence two or three instruction steps to achieve a desired outcome.

FAD675C645104E92871D425511CAB4B2.description: Determine if instructions with two or three steps given in different orders still produce the desired outcome.

F71CF1B0274F4919936C11ED6ADB9E78.description: Follow instructions with two or three steps given in different forms.

2B62FDFE19A745679BCC4D4F77A63F56.description: Instructions help to keep people safe.

B71C0CC1F92745F292D1A57CD58AD6DB.description: Instructions are ordered in a way that will produce a desired outcome.

5796D85CF2D34391A9B7DA9A9221050F.description: The form in which instructions are given may not affect the outcome.

5D792E50A76F458A8688A8F8F4FD84B9.description: Following instructions is a way to demonstrate respect and safety during investigations.

1A9C90DF83C949E6A78C5BEA3B8D87A6.description: Many types of instructions need to be in a specific order, such as directions, recipes, computer programs and safety protocols

BBBD608ED2154C23B2754D6030BAA2CA.description: Instructions are directions that can be followed and given in various forms, including verbal, audio, visual and written.

3179939DC98344569C0D16A132E08B3A.description: Students follow instructions and relate them to outcomes

1BAAE933D22A4333A690E2F1673FB25C.description: Computer Science: Problem solving and scientific inquiry are developed through the knowledgeable application of creativity, design, and computational thinking.

5642197A85F9493CBC55B83910317032.description: Identify products made by various cultures, including local First Nations, Métis, or Inuit, that use plant and animal parts.

4548A680CDE247FD90B3F3F8EE6232BB.description: Discuss how humans depend on plants and animals to meet their basic needs.

8F8F3E273CF846E4A7C0559E0337EE8C.description: Describe personal experiences related to how humans take care of plants and animals.

189C5DB15E8643EC9A3A0E74F9B0AA79.description: Discuss the movement of local animals from place to place to meet their needs.

323A916EAD45454887C3C747C039E54D.description: Determine how a local environment meets the basic needs of plants and animals.

303162C714134FE8B3E47ADAA783B48E.description: Represent plants and animals in various environments.

0192ABF4FE4D4703BC2BEA6F145098DC.description: Observe and describe similarities and differences between plants and animals.

BB80012A0D894FBBA37990DFCB1C1820.description: Share examples of plants and animals native to Alberta and Canada.

1B62BAB361AD48BB8F81B38125822B3C.description: Humans, other animals, and plants depend on each other to meet their needs.

454B1B7A6B6E498795D1BE7305FD23BE.description: Plants and animals require environments that allow them to meet their needs.

A49D3F42EB9646D08D4DB646E47AFF2D.description: Plants and animals share similarities and have differences.

45ECDA4E739C4AEC94921EEB9A963FE1.description: Ways that plants and animals, or their parts, help meet the needs of humans include providing air for breathing, food, clothing, shelter, medicine, and connection (social/emotional)

64B65080CE4242DCADC014D8DFB06EC5.description: Ways humans can help meet the needs of plants or animals include watering plants, taking care of domestic animals and respecting environments

FB6B062B24B9499CB1A03DF4D4B7A22F.description: Basic needs of plants and animals include food, water, air and shelter

DAA3D7E5E1D141C9873CA70E56D16D19.description: Diverse plants and animals can be found in many environments in Alberta, such as forests, prairies, lakes and rivers mountains

E1C0364BD2F24A7FBA659A156D6AE24E.description: A variety of plants and animals exist and are dispersed over Earth.

EFA8147822854554B1A49B09D40E09F6.description: Humans are part of nature and are classified as animals.

FBE8DAC478B246B890C6B44E31B0B2E8.description: Plants and animals exist in all shapes and sizes.

383450A00EB64811A20C381D9C13FC88.description: Animals are usually able to move from place to place.

F335DEEF8606419C93816F9A077AE2DC.description: Animals are living things that can grow and that need to find food.

991F3EF488B649B88629B89E6E01EE61.description: Plants usually cannot move from place to place.

C6175E66DC114D55ABF44562B26C63B6.description: Plants are living things that can grow and make their own food.

0875ADFD09924C26950DFC219DF1CAF7.description: Students investigate and examine needs of plants and animals.

BCEBD7B7510D4EC0B936157C01542470.description: Living Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

0B2581E859B646CE985487DC4E909C47.description: Discuss and reflect on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit traditional teachings that demonstrate a sense of responsibility to care for nature.

638E111DED894364A883FA4B927D8EFB.description: Identify personal and group actions that demonstrate responsibility and care for nature.

894B0CAA31B14DAD8780A360E3829A2C.description: Discuss benefits of spending time in nature.

A19149B01CEB4D75906E272A98218E6A.description: Describe how seasonal changes affect decisions about daily activities.

93AE20267C064D5DA8361B318226CF87.description: Describe various environments, drawing from information gathered using the senses.

4C3A5CCA5E7A4A38B68851471EEF5175.description: Share personal experiences related to sudden changes in environments.

37A0A2F2EF0944C28910027222F57B10.description: Investigate animal behaviour throughout the seasons, including migration and hibernation.

F89814C2B45742E3ADB4935206032149.description: Represent an environment in different seasons to show environmental changes.

BEE41F957CE847E0991CF09A23B0A022.description: Discuss how changes in the appearance of environments, plants, and animals are related to the seasons.

A22AC0A72DEC484793C96977ED9FB824.description: Share personal experiences related to seasons.

0D0D29E8F96F4419813A6DBA7354EB46.description: Document signs of seasonal change over time.

1E62A2F2EA544A5A8C574CBF076E18CA.description: Observe seasonal changes in local environments over time.

6CB1A7312B2641E6B22EAE2A3CA9ACCA.description: Caring for nature comes from a sense of responsibility.

DCECAD9F756F48B989ADC85037957F65.description: Seasonal changes influence decisions about daily activities

50C34A3357E44882B5BE7FCFF1F1EC08.description: Environments are observed and understood using the senses.

8D863372E3EA44CE8CEBBCC9F26289E5.description: Seasonal or sudden changes can affect the behaviour of animals.

71F47DC08B1C41E394693876EE4D8373.description: Changes in environments include seasonal changes.

F073C6A6AF4144B39E4868DBEDEEBBEB.description: For First Nations, Métis, and Inuit, a sense of responsibility toward nature can be connected to place and traditional teachings for future generations, such as taking only what is needed.

C2CDED39193540C68C40CF27F7F805DC.description: The responsibility to care for environments is shared by all people and is fulfilled by showing respect for and protecting all aspects of nature.

50A061FEB32E40B9A6CC84B79F0FC118.description: Seasonal changes may affect a variety of choices and activities, such as clothing choices, recreational activities, Indigenous ceremonies and hunting and gathering

9349472E47DE4829A8F8E3F1270E2B7A.description: Information can be gathered from environments using the senses.

B3E013BEA6714AB8AFE53B7B4F9666D2.description: Environments can undergo sudden changes, such as storms, floods, fires and winds

6A3BCF9BF14A4EC0B94ED760726184E2.description: Many animals hibernate in winter, such as black bears and grizzly bears, groundhogs and some types of squirrels

01262E43FB9441F98D2F319C01EA1DC5.description: Hibernation allows animals to survive the winter with little or no food, usually by sleeping for long periods of time.

66E9262AA5E24F4AABD79193B3B3EFDC.description: Many animals migrate, such as whales, geese, polar bears, butterflies and caribou

E970ECF0433345F79322055DBEBB057F.description: Migration is the regular movement patterns of animals from one area to another, usually in response to seasonal changes.

47F8285973A94FBE9DB2387F250AD128.description: Seasonal changes appear in plants and animals, such as camouflage in animals, leaves changing colour and falling, flowers blooming  and crops and plants greening and growing

4F1C1A3FDA584AF68BB40E19B3C61EF8.description: Many seasonal changes appear in environments, such as snow covering the ground, snow melting, the surface of lakes and other bodies of water freezing  and rivers flowing fast or slow

0D280C4588F340C8A7FDCF5212128E37.description: Some places have fewer than four seasons, such as  two seasons: rainy and dry and three seasons: cool or cold, rainy, and dry

0D2DE0458F6546D9876BB36FB6DC64E7.description: The four seasons in Alberta are summer , autumn or fall , winter and spring

C4AA2619D1FB45689756F4C1787FEE35.description: Students analyze environments and investigate interactions and changes.

836963CE456E4B30A9FC636F95DEB5DF.description: Earth Systems: Understandings of the living world, Earth, and space are deepened by investigating natural systems and their interactions.

B5782634CF2340D1B8A8BEA02C6B481C.description: Demonstrate how the movement of objects can be influenced.

AB9CB3919D2E472B9141351506B14881.description: Describe and record ways objects or animals move along different pathways.

4F619329DBC54684BE3C404CCED94444.description: Conduct an investigation to determine how objects move.

2DB11E868B5E4D9B87E88D1D16ECFF04.description: Observe and describe the direction, pathway, and speed of objects or animals.

4AAB0D43BEB947DE9665BA3B001E5E14.description: The movement of objects can be influenced in a variety of ways.

42B261F83F2E44A8A48581A763304AAC.description: Movement consists of direction, a pathway, and speed.

75D62682B8524CECADAEBAFB6C2D8982.description: Wheels can make objects easier to move.

87338669E04C48FEA249B21F0FE704F5.description: The movement of objects can be influenced by the shape of the object , the materials the object is made from , the surface texture of the object  and interactions with other objects

247FB4A1A7144452B9030FE0CE207C20.description: Speed can be described as fast, slow, changing and not changing

B71B78E099BF49BCB6784E798AFB4E68.description: Objects or animals move along pathways in a variety of ways, such as rolling, bouncing and sliding

7CAFE61A58D64D1F845F68914A0D9994.description: Movement pathways can be described as straight, curved, spiral, side to side

718200B14FCB42FAA217949515AE6296.description: A movement pathway is the path an object or animal follows when it moves.

EA96CD772FA04DA6B45475DC9275D7C1.description: Directions of movement can be described as up, down, forward, backward, sideways, toward and away from

384DA0ED69DD44BFB8213C176BDA9791.description: Students investigate direction, pathway, and speed of moving objects and animals.

0D7E7FFBA35F4810AC5B6C915D3CEA42.description: Energy: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.

2F72A97940414C269D79824DEB5A874F.description: Discuss why physical changes do not change what an object is made of.

B195CEE5258644A18EA66CE505C0A7D5.description: Describe physical changes that result from various actions.

A3F7F2E74F9F4BA0809A464742DFA06F.description: Explore actions that physically change properties of various objects.

9586F40412A64D7F80CA9E7F95977822.description: Predict how actions can physically change properties of various objects.

E39E21E8D98E4E3C9D2F2FBA71CB06CF.description: Use various tools safely when examining the properties of objects.

B609D2AC96D54893B23EB666A44D5E4E.description: Directly compare the length, area, and weight of various objects.

8F964381F1E84891B59006CD164B6064.description: Physical changes to objects do not change what the objects are made of.

15EC2884F7A9422BB08C52D3CCF8A21F.description: Not all objects respond the same way to bending, twisting, stretching, cutting, or breaking.

DCB17BAA05004C16BFEC44EC16EA5283.description: Actions that physically change properties of an object include bending , twisting , stretching , cutting  and breaking

7566E5F0D4CE49209721FBF8590AAE5B.description: Properties that can be changed include length, area, weight (mass), shape and texture

683C9FD1AC6448978AE6AF9365C18C37.description: Tools, such as balance scales and magnifying glasses, can be used to examine properties of objects and materials.

F0B41D72C5644A4A9A0E9D31D3F3B337.description: Weight is the heaviness of an object.

B11512C5F34D4A1893D72E32D8483C29.description: Measurable properties of objects include  length  how much flat space an object covers (area)  weight (mass)

FDFA2EEE1FBB41FB8A31312DA1C591F4.description: Students analyze properties of objects and investigate how they can be changed.

400B7741EA824A0A809A923D68E95D57.description: Matter: Understandings of the physical world are deepened by investigating matter and energy.
